# Part II

## *landscapemetrics*: An open-source R tool to calculate landscape metrics

Maximilian H.K. Hesselbarth

Department of Ecosystem Modelling, University of Goettingen, Germany

---
# Introdution to landscape metrics

--
- Tools to quantify composition and configuration of landscapes

  - Composition: number and abundance of land-cover classes
  - Configuration: spatial arrangement of land-cover classes


--
- Designed for discrete patches of different land-cover classes

<center> 

--
.pull-left[
```{r aerial_lsm, out.width = "75%", out.height = "75%", echo = FALSE}
knitr::include_graphics("figs/aerial_lsm.png")
```
]

.pull-right[
```{r example_lsm, out.width = "75%", out.height = "75%", echo = FALSE}
ras_df <- as.data.frame(landscapemetrics::landscape, xy = TRUE)

ggplot(data = ras_df) + 
  geom_raster(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(clumps))) + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#98D2E1", "#EAB8BD", "#9B9555")) +
  guides(fill = FALSE) +
  coord_equal() + 
  theme_void() + 
  theme(plot.margin = unit(c(0, 0, 0, 0), "mm"))
```
]

</center>

---
# Why a new R package was needed

--
- *FRAGSTATS*  <font size="3" color="grey"> (McGarigal et al., 2012) </font> 
  
  - <font color = "#63C03C"> Comprehensive collection of metrics </font> 
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Only on Windows, not open source </font> 
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Need to import/export data </font> 
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Hard to integrate into larger workflows </font> 


--
- *SDMTools* (R package) <font size="3" color="grey"> (VanDerWal et al., 2019) </font> 
  
  - <font color = "#63C03C"> Multiplatform, open source </font>
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Only set of metrics, no metrics on landscape level </font> 
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Hard to integrate into larger workflows </font> 
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Not on CRAN anymore (archived on 12.01.2020) </font> 


--
- Several GIS add-ons (e.g. *r.li* <font size="3" color="grey"> (Porta et al., 2017) </font>))
  
  - <font color = "#63C03C"> Multiplatform, open source </font>
  - <font color = "#64AAC5"> Need to use GIS software </font>

# The R package *landscapemetrics*

--
- Based on *raster* package <font size="3" color="grey"> (Hijmans 2017) </font>


--
- Allows to calculate landscape metrics in transparent and reproducible workflow


--
- Tidy <font size="3" color="grey"> (sensu Wickham 2014) </font> and type-stable output of all metric functions


--
- Includes many utility functions for e.g. plotting or sampling

<br>
<center>

--
```{r levels_lsm, fig.hold = "hold", out.width="30%", echo = FALSE}

lsm_patch <- get_patches(landscape, class = 1)[[1]] %>% 
  as.data.frame(xy = TRUE) %>% 
  mutate(level = "patch") %>% 
  rename(clumps = layer) %>% 
  ggplot() + 
    geom_raster(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(clumps))) + 
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("#85D4E3", "#F4B5BD", "#9C964A", "#CDC08C", 
                                 "#FAD77B", "#B77F46", "#282220", "#E0D146", 
                                 "#D18F41"),
                      na.value = "grey75") +
    guides(fill = FALSE) +
    labs(title = "Patch level") +
    coord_equal() + 
    theme_void(base_size = 17.5) + 
    theme(plot.margin = unit(c(0, 0, 0, 0), "mm"), 
          text = element_text(family = "Metropolis"))

lsm_class <- as.data.frame(landscape, xy = TRUE) %>% 
  mutate(clumps = case_when(clumps == 1 ~ 1), 
         level = "class") %>% 
  ggplot() + 
    geom_raster(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(clumps))) + 
    scale_fill_manual(values = "#98D2E1", na.value = "grey75") +
    guides(fill = FALSE) +
    labs(title = "Class level") +
    coord_equal() + 
    theme_void(base_size = 17.5) + 
    theme(plot.margin = unit(c(0, 0, 0, 0), "mm"), 
          text = element_text(family = "Metropolis"))

lsm_landscape <- as.data.frame(landscape, xy = TRUE) %>% 
  mutate(level = "landscape") %>% 
  ggplot() + 
    geom_raster(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(clumps))) + 
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("#98D2E1", "#EAB8BD", "#9B9555")) +
    guides(fill = FALSE) +
    labs(title = "Landscape level") +
    coord_equal() + 
    theme_void(base_size = 17.5) + 
    theme(plot.margin = unit(c(0, 0, 0, 0), "mm"), 
          text = element_text(family = "Metropolis"))

lsm_patch 
lsm_class
lsm_landscape
```

</center>

# Getting ready to use *landscapemetrics*

--
Import and check data

```{r check_lsm}
# install.packages("landscapemetrics")

data <- raster("data/example_landscape.tif") 
landscapemetrics::check_landscape(data)
```

--
List available metrics

```{r list_metrics}
landscapemetrics::list_lsm()
```

---
# How to calculate landscape metrics

--
.pull-left[

Calculate single metric

```{r simple_calc_a}
landscapemetrics::lsm_p_area(data)
```
]

--
.pull-right[

Combine several metrics to one *tibble*

```{r simple_calc_b}
class_mean <- landscapemetrics::lsm_c_area_mn(data)
lsm_total <- landscapemetrics::lsm_l_ta(data)

bind_rows(class_mean, lsm_total)
```
]

---
# Easy integration into larger workflows

--
Integrate easily into larger workflows

```{r larger_workflow}
set.seed(42)

sample(x = c(1, 2, 3), prob = c(0.5, 0.25, 0.25), size = 2500, replace = TRUE) %>%
  matrix(nrow = 50, ncol = 50) %>%
  raster::raster() %>%
  landscapemetrics::lsm_p_enn() %>% #<<
  dplyr::filter(value <= quantile(value, probs = 0.25) | value >= quantile(value, probs = 0.75)) %>%
  dplyr::group_by(class) %>%
  dplyr::summarise(n = n()) %>%
  dplyr::arrange(-n)
```

---
# Calculation of multiple metrics

--
Easily calculate multiple metrics based on e.g. level and type

```{r multiple_metrics}
calculate_lsm(landscape = data, 
              level = "landscape", type = "diversity metric", 
              classes_max = 5)
```

##  First practical part

Try to work through *Exercise_1.R*. The exercise will teach you how to calculate single and multiple landscape metrics. Furthermore, you will learn how to integrate *landscapemetrics* into larger workflows using e.g. the *tidyverse* <font size="3" color="grey"> (Wickham et al. 2019) </font>. 

During the exercise there are part where you are supposed to code your own solution indicated by the following structure:

```{r exercise_code_1, eval = FALSE}
# /Start Code/ #

print("Hello World") # This would be your code contribution

# /End Code/ # 
```

In case you run into problems or have any questions, please contact us at any time via *Zoom* private chat. Also, there will be a public Q&A plenary session at **XX:XX pm**.

For a general overview of *landscapemetrics*, please see <https://r-spatialecology.github.io/landscapemetrics>.

# Sample metrics in buffer areas

--
- Samples metrics in a buffer area (sample plot) around sample points 

--
- Also able to use sample lines or  *sp*-SpatialPolygons. 

--
- Metrics can be specified identical to `list_lsm()` and `calculate_lsm()`

--
```{r, plot_sample_points, echo = FALSE, fig.align = "center"}
sample_points <- matrix(c(1253709, 1249455, 
                          1261857, 1256055,
                          1252009, 1257055), ncol = 2, byrow = TRUE)

buffer <- landscapemetrics::construct_buffer(coords = sample_points, 
                                             size = 1000, shape = "square", 
                                             return_sp = FALSE)

ggplot(data = raster::as.data.frame(augusta_nlcd, xy = TRUE)) + 
  geom_raster(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = nlcd_2011_landcover_2011_edition_2014_10_10_NLCD.2011.Land.Cover.Class)) +
  geom_point(data = data.frame(sample_points), aes(x = X1, y = X2), pch = 1) +
  geom_polygon(data = data.frame(buffer), aes(x = X1, y = X2, group = X3), 
               fill = NA, col = "black") +
  coord_equal() + 
  scale_fill_manual(name = "", values = c("Herbaceuous" = "#FDE9AA", 
                                          "Evergreen Forest" = "#38814E", 
                                          "Deciduous Forest" = "#85C77E", 
                                          "Hay/Pasture" = "#FBF65D", 
                                          "Developed, Open Space" = "#E8D1D1", 
                                          "Mixed Fores" = "#D4E7B0", 
                                          "Shrub/Scrub" = "#DCCA8F", 
                                          "Open Water" = "#5475A8", 
                                          "Woody Wetlands" = "#C8E6F8", 
                                          "Developed, Low Intensity" = "#E29E8C", 
                                          "Developed, Medium Intensity" = "#FF0000", 
                                          "Developed, High Intensity" = "#B50000", 
                                          "Barren Land" = "#D2CDC0", 
                                          "Emergent Herbaceuous Wetlands" = "#FDE9AA", 
                                          "Cultivated Crops" = "#CA9146")) +
  guides(fill = FALSE) + 
  theme_void()
```

# Moving window

--
- Show gradients and variability in the landscape

--
- Use matrix to specify moving window and focal cell

--
```{r moving_window_plot, echo = FALSE, fig.align = "center"}
focal_i <- cbind(ras_df[ ,c(1,2)], id = 1:nrow(ras_df))

focal_poly <- purrr::map_dfr(1:nrow(focal_i), function(i) {
  
  focal_i[i, c(1,2)]
  
  x_min <- focal_i[i, 1] - 4.5
  x_max <- focal_i[i, 1] + 4.5
  
  y_min <- focal_i[i, 2] - 4.5
  y_max <- focal_i[i, 2] + 4.5
  
  data.frame(x = c(x_min, x_max, x_max, x_min), 
             y = c(y_min, y_min, y_max, y_max))
}, .id = "id")

focal_poly$id <- as.integer(focal_poly$id)

# focal_poly <- focal_poly[which(focal_poly$x > 0 & focal_poly$y > 0), ]

gg_window <- ggplot(data = ras_df) + 
  geom_raster(aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(clumps))) + 
  geom_point(data = focal_i, aes(x = x, y = y), pch = 1) +
  geom_polygon(data = focal_poly, aes(x = x, y = y),
               fill = NA, col = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#98D2E1", "#EAB8BD", "#9B9555")) +
  guides(fill = FALSE) +
  coord_equal() + 
  theme_void() + 
  transition_states(id,
                    transition_length = 2,
                    state_length = 1)

gganimate::animate(gg_window, nframes = 900, fps = 10, duration = 90)
```

# Building blocks

--
Fast building blocks to create your own metrics

--
.pull-left[

*raster* package

```{r adj_raster}
adj_raster <- function(x) {
  adjacencies <- 
    raster::adjacent(x, cells = 1:ncell(x))
  table(x[adjacencies[, 1]], x[adjacencies[, 2]])
}
adj_raster(landscape)
```
]

--
.pull-right[

`landscapemetrics` package

```{r adj_lsm}
get_adjacencies(landscape)
```
]

--
```{r bench, eval = FALSE}
# A tibble: 2 x 3 
expression                      mean        mem_alloc
<chr>                           <bch:tm>    <bch:byt>
1 adj_raster(landscape)         8900 μs     1470 KB
2 get_adjacencies(landscape)    562 μs      6 KB
```
